translation.text: The True Guru, the True Guru, the True Guru is the Lord of the Universe Himself.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Gayand
author.description:
Poet Gayand [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Gayand wrote thirteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Gayand also uses the popular Sikh mantra Vaheguru for the first time in the entire Guru Granth Sahib. He was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Kalshar.

text: ਬਲਿਹਿ ਛਲਨ ਸਬਲ ਮਲਨ ਭਗ੍ਤਿ ਫਲਨ ਕਾਨ੍ਹ ਕੁਅਰ ਨਿਹਕਲੰਕ ਬਜੀ ਡੰਕ ਚੜ੍ਹੂ ਦਲ ਰਵਿੰਦ ਜੀਉ ॥

translation.text: Enticer of Baliraja, who smothers the mighty, and fulfills the devotees; the Prince Krishna, and Kalki; the thunder of His army and the beat of His drum echoes across the Universe.

transliteration.text: balih shalan sabal malan bhagt phalan kānh kuar nihakalank bajī dank charhū dal ravind jīu .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Gayand
author.description:
Poet Gayand [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Gayand wrote thirteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Gayand also uses the popular Sikh mantra Vaheguru for the first time in the entire Guru Granth Sahib. He was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Kalshar.

text: ਰਾਮ ਰਵਣ ਦੁਰਤ ਦਵਣ ਸਕਲ ਭਵਣ ਕੁਸਲ ਕਰਣ ਸਰਬ ਭੂਤ ਆਪਿ ਹੀ ਦੇਵਾਧਿ ਦੇਵ ਸਹਸ ਮੁਖ ਫਨਿੰਦ ਜੀਉ ॥

translation.text: The Lord of contemplation, Destroyer of sin, who brings pleasure to the beings of all realms, He Himself is the God of gods, Divinity of the divine, the thousand-headed king cobra.

transliteration.text: rām ravan durat davan sakal bhavan kusal karan sarab bhūt āp hī dēvādh dēv sahas mukh phanind jīu .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Gayand
author.description:
Poet Gayand [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Gayand wrote thirteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Gayand also uses the popular Sikh mantra Vaheguru for the first time in the entire Guru Granth Sahib. He was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Kalshar.

text: ਜਰਮ ਕਰਮ ਮਛ ਕਛ ਹੁਅ ਬਰਾਹ ਜਮੁਨਾ ਕੈ ਕੂਲਿ ਖੇਲੁ ਖੇਲਿਓ ਜਿਨਿ ਗਿੰਦ ਜੀਉ ॥

translation.text: He took birth in the Incarnations of the Fish, Tortoise and Wild Boar, and played His part. He played games on the banks of the Jamunaa River.

transliteration.text: jaram karam mash kash hu barāh jamunā kai kūl khēl khēliō jin gind jīu .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Gayand
author.description:
Poet Gayand [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Gayand wrote thirteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Gayand also uses the popular Sikh mantra Vaheguru for the first time in the entire Guru Granth Sahib. He was the son of Chokha, and brother of Poet Kalshar.

text: ਨਾਮੁ ਸਾਰੁ ਹੀਏ ਧਾਰੁ ਤਜੁ ਬਿਕਾਰੁ ਮਨ ਗਯੰਦ ਸਤਿਗੁਰੂ ਸਤਿਗੁਰੂ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਗੁਬਿੰਦ ਜੀਉ ॥੪॥੯॥

translation.text: Enshrine this most excellent Name within your heart, and renounce the wickedness of the mind, O Gayand the True Guru, the True Guru, the True Guru is the Lord of the Universe Himself. ||4||9||

transliteration.text: nām sār hīē dhār taj bikār man gayand satigurū satigurū satigur gubind jīu .4.9.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
